page.title: 14Landscape of St. Agnes
page.content: Basically this area presents a rural landscape with bleak and rugged scenery in parts. There is a decided lack of trees - which is apparent when visiting the south coast. There, the landscape is much softer. Dotted about the landscape are relics of the more prosperous tin-mining days in St. Agnes - old engine houses, mine stacks, and remains of the workings from the mines. In the distance may be seen the rugged cliffs that abound with heather and lichen. During the spring, broom and gorse also adorn the hedgerows making a blaze of bright yellow. The highest hill is The Beacon, at St. Agnes, which stands 650 feet above sea level. This was chosen as one of the principal stations in the Great Trigonometrical Survey. The 'trig point' can be seen clearly from afar.
